div.p: 1. V:15— Sunday.

Mr Peter Whitney performed the services of the morning, and preached from Proverbs 13.21. [“]Evil pursueth sinners.”— A plain Discourse easily divided into illustrations of the manner in which evil pursues the different classes of Sinners.— The dishonest man—the intemperate man—the profane swearer—he did not touch upon the gambler, the fornicator, the infidel; nor specially upon the hypocrite— He had difficulty in reading his Discourse—his eyes, his teeth, his voice, his Memory are all in decay; his articulation is so indistinct, and his utterance so feeble that I heard not more than half his Sermon— Mr Degrand came out from Boston and brought budgets of newspapers and news from Philadelphia and New-York.— Richard Haughton Editor of the Boston Atlas came from Philadelphia yesterday morning at 9. O’Clock and brought reports of the election of Presidential Electors, the day before in Philadelphia, and the adjoining Counties of Bucks, Chester and Delaware— The result in the four Counties is favourable to the whigs, but the authenticity of the returns is not sure, and the gain is so small that there is little hope of Pennsylvania— The New-York papers are filled with electioneering plots and counterplots from which I cannot escape the conclusion that fraud and violence, are creeping and breaking fearfully into our elections— These practices were first introduced by the mob government party, who call themselves democrats, and one of their most impudent devices, is to charge their adversaries with their own crimes.— This they did but too successfully in the case of the New-Jersey election, and they are playing the same game over again in New-York. Mr Lunt performed the afternoon services, and preached from Genesis 25.27. [“]And the boys grew: and Esau was a cunning hunter, a man of the field; and Jacob was a plain man, dwelling in tents.” a beautifully contrasted character of the two brothers and of their fortunes and descendants— He attributed this to the difference of their religious principles: and while tracing the sublime and melancholy series of vicissitudes which have distinguished the children of Israel from the days of their progenitor down to their present dispersion all over the earth he marked its transcendent superiority over the brief prosperity and awful extinction of the race of the Edomites and the recently discovered ruins of their city upon the rock, now called, Petra. He referred to the 49th chapter of Jeremiah, the 25th. of Isaiah, and the prophesy of Obadiah.— Mr Degrand left us about 8. P.M. Mr Beale and his daughter Caroline were afterwards here. John Quincy and Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us.
2. V:30. Monday

Mr Isaac T. Smith came from Boston this morning with his Sister and proposed to change the day upon which I should address the New-York Lyceum, as I had conditionally promised on the 11th. of this month. I agreed to substitute the 18th. or the 25th. not being certain that I can reach New-York so early as the 18th and promising that if I cannot, I will give him timely notice. Miss Smith repeated a request which she had made before, and which I had forgotten; for an autograph of my mother, and one of my own— My Son also came out for an hour or two but returned before dinner.— He is nominated as a candidate, one of 35. from Boston, to the House of Representatives in the Legislature of this Commonwealth— It was urged upon him last year, but he declined. We had an early dinner; and at two O’Clock P.M. my wife, with Mrs John Adams, her daughter Mary-Louisa, and Jeremy Leary, left our House at Quincy to take the Stonington Railroad Cars at 4. for New-York, and Washington. Elizabeth C. Adams who had passed the Night here, went home to her mother’s, and I remained with Louisa C. Smith to go to the City to-morrow— I was under peine forte et dure with occupations—but Mr William Ellis of Dedham came and spent two hours of the afternoon, with me about the Pension claims of Relief Dunbar and others, the Pension of Benjamin Buzzey, Ogle’s speech, the furniture of the President’s house and other gossip. About Sunset Mr Horatio Moore, and Mr Burton came in from Waltham. I had written to Mr Nelson Moore, that I would deliver a Lecture to the Adams Association there next Saturday evening. They came to say, that by a previous engagement of the whig Association at Waltham the town hall would be occupied by Mr Robert C. Winthrop and Mr Franklin Dexter, in addressing the whigs on Saturday Evening, and it would be necessary to change the Evening for my Lecture to the Adams association, and I accordingly agreed to go, next Tuesday Evening, instead of Saturday— They wished me also to go to be there at an early hour of the Evening; and I agreed to be ready at my Son’s house, from half past 3 to 4 of the afternoon for the Carriage which they are to engage to take me to Waltham and back.— Being in some perplexity with regard to the second of my political Lectures, which is dry, dull, and too political, I took an old unfinished Essay upon Society written about twenty years ago, and wrote two pages, merely to bring it to a close, and I shall endeavour to pass that off for a Lecture.— It was written at leisure and is therefore much better composition than any thing that I can write now— Of course my labour upon the Chinese lecture is suspended, and I am ready to give it up in despair— I wrote unremittingly from the dusk of Evening till half past 11. when I retired to my solitary bed.

div.dateline: Quincy— Boston. Tuesday 3. November 1840— Charlestown. Boston
div.p: 3. V. Tuesday—
White frost. Fahrenheit 30.

At 8. O’Clock this morning, I departed from Quincy in Gillet’s Omnibus, with Louisa C. Smith leaving home as usual in great haste, and all my books and papers in confusion. We took up Passengers all the way along till there were twelve women, two babies, and 3 men, myself included in the Stage, of whom the only person except Miss Smith, whom I knew was Elisha Turner; though his wife and daughter were of the party.— Louisa C. Smith alighted at Mr James H. Foster’s, and I was set down at my son’s house N. 3 Hancock Avenue— Dr George Parkman having met the Stage on Washington Street got in and came with me to the door, leaving with me, an invitation to come and see him.— I remained at Charles’s till 6. in the Evening; before dinner, Mr Edmund Terry, a son of a former member of Congress from Connecticut, but now an inhabitant of Brooklyn, Long-Island, came to repeat an invitation to me from the Hamilton Literary Association at Brooklyn; to deliver a Lecture there on Wednesday the 19th. of this month, which I promised to do, if I could reach and stay at New-York till that time— While we were at dinner, Mr Gould came in, and I agreed with him, to dine with the managers of the Society for the diffusion of useful knowledge at the Tremont house next Saturday.— I had received an invitation from Dr Francis Parkman, to dine with him and the Trustees of the humane Society next Friday.— At 6 O’Clock, Mr Warren came with a Carriage, and took me over, to his house at Charlestown. I walked thence with him just before 7. to the town-hall, which was already filled with a crowded auditory.— As the Clock struck 7. Mr Warren announced to the Lyceum, that the Lecture next Tuesday Evening would be delivered by Professor Henry Ware junr of Cambridge, and would be entitled the biography of the Globe— He then introduced me with a complimentary phrase; and I said that as a Lecture was announced to them for next Tuesday on the biography of the globe I might call that which I was about to deliver to them, the biography of man— And I delivered the Dissertation on Society, which was listened to, with deep and silent attention, and a hearty clap of approbation at the close— I then returned with Mr Warren, who is a lawyer at Charlestown, to his house where I met a numerous party of Gentlemen; and after an hour of conversation, and a plentiful supper I returned to my Son’s house at Boston. Mr Bates a Son of the late Chaplain of the House of Representatives at Washington came home with me, and we met Charles at his door— I rejoiced that I had taken his advice, and substituted this Lecture, for that which I had prepared on Democracy.
4. III— VII Wednesday

On lighting my lamps this morning I found it was but 3. O’Clock—but I was wide awake, and Charles’s study adjoining my bed chamber was well-warmed— So I sat down in my flannel gown two hours, and wrote the diary of yesterday— I then returned to bed, and lay till 7. in repose, if with little or no sleep— Mr Foster came with a Letter from Charles W. Brewster, Secretary of the Lyceum at Portsmouth N.H. inviting me to deliver a Lecture before them on Tuesday the 17th. or any other day of that week— Mr Foster said he was going this day to Portsmouth, to bring home his wife who has been spending some days there at his brothers. I desired him to inform Mr Brewster that I shall be obliged to proceed to Washington, on the 17th. and to say that I would answer his Letter— Mr Curtis of Roxbury came and left with me a Letter, from Petty Vaughan, unimportant and invited me to dine with him, next week on Thursday, and to deliver a Lecture that evening before their Lyceum; which invitation I accepted— I returned to Mr Curtis the Note from Moses Gill to Mrs Boylston— I visited at Mr Abbott Lawrence’s, Mr B. W. Crowninshield’s, and Dr G. Parkman’s but neither of them was at home— Dr. Frothingham called and passed an hour with me.— and afterwards Dr. G. Parkman—with whom I promised to dine, next Wednesday— As I was preparing to start for Salem, Mrs Charles told me that Harriet Welsh had been with her, and advised that I should deliver this Evening at Salem, and to morrow at Boston the Lecture on Faith, and not that upon civilization; several persons who had heard both, much preferring the first. I walked down to the ferry boat at Lewis’s wharf, and precisely at 6 p.m crossed to Chelsea; took the Cars of the Eastern rail-road for Salem, and at a quarter before 7. found Mr N. Silsbee, and Mr Joseph E Sprague, waiting for me at the depot.— Mr Silsbee had a carriage ready, and took me to his house, where I found, his eldest daughter Mrs Sparks; with a little girl, Mr Sparks’s daughter by his first wife—Georgiana, Mr Silsbee’s second daughter, and Miss Storrow of Cambridge. Just before 7. Mr Silsbee took me to the Lyceum Hall, which was as full as it could hold, and the whole company rose as I entered. On the stand at the further end of the Hall, were Chief Justice Shaw—Judges Putnam, Wilde and White, Dr Flint, Dr Hezekiah Packard, Mr Upham, and several other respectable gentlemen— I delivered the Lecture on Faith which was well received, though without any clapping of hands— We then returned to Mr Silsbee’s where about 30. gentlemen came, and spent the remainder of the Evening— I sat in conversation with the family till Midnight.
5. V— VII. Thursday.

I had obtained from Mr Silsbee pens and ink, to write this morning before day-light— I rose at 5. but found the chamber so cold that I was obliged to give it up.— I returned to bed, and lay till 7— After breakfast Mr Silsbee walked with me, and I called to see Mr Upham, but he was not at home— We returned to Mr Silsbees, where several Gentlemen called to see me.— At 11. Mr Silsbee accompanied me to the depot, where I found Mr and Mrs Upham (she is a daughter of the late Dr Holmes of Cambridge, and a Grand-daughter of Oliver Wendell of former times[)]. There were several others among others Mr Treadwell who came on with me in the Cars to Boston— At the landing at East-Boston, I met Mr Kavenagh recently returned from Lisbon, where he has been several years chargé d’Affaires of the United States and where he has concluded a Treaty— I found Charles’s servant-man Edward waiting for me at the depot. After crossing the river I met Mr Stephen C. Phillips, now Mayor of Salem, who was absent from that City yesterday, and now returning home.— I reached Charles’s house, a quarter past 12. and Doctor George Parkman almost immediately after came in, then Mrs. Angier from Medford, who wished but had been unable to procure tickets for this Evening’s Lecture at the Masonic temple— The Society for the diffusion of useful knowledge, issuing no tickets for one evening but only for the whole course; but Dr Parkman undertook to procure two tickets for Mr and Mrs Angier; and did procure them, and they were sent to Mrs Angier, at Mr Edward Miller’s where she dined. Then Harriet Welsh, who held an argument with me to prevail upon me to deliver the lecture on Faith, instead of that upon civilization—and Mr Warren from Charlestown, who gave me a note from Mrs S. C. Alden, wife of Lieutenant Alden, one of the Officers of the exploring expedition, with a sample of a small fragment of stone from an Iceberg on the newly discovered Antarctic continent, and a slip extracted from a Sidney Newspapers, in New South Wales. Mr Warren told me that the Managers of the Charlestown Lyceum had determined to give the 15 dollars which according to their rules they had offered me, and which I had declined accepting to an infant school Association, with direction to receive it a donation from me— Immediately after dinner Mr Degrand came in with MrSturgis who has been several years in China; and with whom I had some conversation relating to that Country— Charles went and delivered a whig Lecture at Quincy— Mr and Mrs Carey came about 6. and Mrs Charles and her daughter Louisa Catherine went with them. Mr Gould accompanied me to the Temple where I delivered the Lecture on Civilization—house crowded— The Lecture well received. Harriet Welsh and Thomas Frothingham walked home with us, and passed an hour here. Bed about 10—
6. V. Friday.

Mrs Mary Jane Lawrence came, this morning, and represented to me with many tears her distressed condition, for want of the pension to which she thinks herself entitled as the widow of a man, who served as a Soldier in the last War with Great-Britain, and died in the service— Her case is one of those, upon which the existing Law grants a pension for five years which she has received. She cannot perceive the humanity of a Law which grants a pension for five Years and then stops it.— Nor do I— But Congress have hitherto inflexibly adhered to it, and I could not give Mrs Lawrence any cheering hope of a more liberal temper at the approaching Session— Dr George Parkman was here, and proposed to me to go with him to morrow Morning and visit the pauper establishments of the town at South-Boston, of which he says there are three, and I agreed to go— He told me that the man of the ticket office at the Masonic Temple, told him that there were 5000 persons turned off last evening, because there was no room to admit them into the Hall— Perhaps 5000 meant 200— Harriet Welsh came and I went with her and visited Mrs George T. Lee, to thank her for a copy of a Memoir of the Life of Miss Hannah Adams written by herself, and which Mrs Lee had printed a few years since, with a preface by herself— It was not printed for publication; but Mrs Lee had sent me a copy of it at the time when it was printed— I wanted last Summer another copy to send to Mrs M. Harrison Smith, and Harriet Welsh obtained it for me from Mrs George T. Bigelow— I sent it to Mrs Harrison Smith, and received a few days since from her a Letter of thanks; saying that she valued so highly the volume that she could not think of parting with it, and would have it transcribed to send to Mr Vail the information which he wanted.— While we were at Mrs Lee’s, Mr. Simmons the ex-abolition preacher at Mobile came in— They spoke of my last Evening’s Lecture, and Mrs Lee expressed a wish to read it— Her hearing is impaired, so that she attends no public Lectures.— I consented to her reading it, and Harriet Welsh asked my leave to take a copy of the two Stanza’s on wedded love, which I introduced into it, last Evening, which I also yielded— She took the Lecture to Mrs. Lee with a promise to return it, in a day or two— Charles returned from Quincy, where he delivered last Evening an Address to the whigs.— Mrs Frothingham, Dr Bigelow, and William Gorham were At 1/2 past three I went with Charles and dined at Dr Francis Parkman’s, with the Trustees of the humane Society— Mrs Parkman the only lady at table.— I had some conversation with Dr Palfrey, about his book and about China— We came home at 8. and Charles and his wife occupied two hours in collating my mother’s Letters for a second Edition.
7. IV. Saturday.

Mr Sidney Brooks was here this morning and invited me to dine next Tuesday; but my engagement to go that afternoon to Waltham did not admit of my dining out here.— Dr George Parkman came and took me over to South-Boston where we visited two of the City Establishments—the hospital for the insane, and the house of correction— Dr Butler being the superintendant of the first,—and Captain Rogers of the second— There are of the insane 97 men and 92 women—each sex in apartments separate from the other—distributed in three stories, one above the other each floor having an entry from side to side of the house with small chambers each side of the entry in each of which was an iron bedstead fastened to the side of the Wall a mattress and comfortable bedding and a chair, each Patient having a separate bed chamber, and all the range of the central-entry to walk about in— All neat and clean, and white-washed to a gloss— Of the inmates all appeared thoroughly and mournfully insane; but not one frantic or violent— All, violently wild, and some menacing in their looks; and three or four, annoyingly talkative— Of the whole number only one woman was confined to her chamber. The hospital for the sick, the bake-house and the kitchen were in different parts of the building and all appeared to be kept in perfect order— The arrangement of the workhouse was similar to that of the hospital, excepting that there was a separate call for each convict, and no common entry where they could communicate with each other. It was just as the men had dined each in his cell, and they were marched out in Indian file, in total silence, and each man, with his arms folded as he marched— The women were all in one large upper chamber seated in rows of chairs one before the other all sewing or knitting in silence without speaking to one another— The are two other establishments in that neighbourhood which we did not see.— The house of correction for vicious boys, and the asylum for the blind— Returning homewards Dr Parkman left me at Mr Abbott Lawrences door, and I paid him a visit— At home, Mr Ripley, the Minister of Waltham invited me to his house when I go to deliver the Lecture, next Tuesday. I said I had engaged to go, to be there about two hours before the Lecture and would cheerfully go to his house, if no other arrangement had been made by the Gentlemen, who are to come for me— Visits from Harriet Welsh, and Mr Edward Brooks, while I was out— At 4. P.M. I went with Charles and dined at the Tremont house, with the managers of the Society for the diffusion of useful knowledge. 16. at table—Dr Frothingham—N. Hale, B. A Gould—Charles Sumner, Mr Falconer an Englishman. Home at 9. P.M.
8. III: VI:30. Sunday.

Rose this morning at 3. O’Clock, went into Charles’s Study, and wrote two hours—then returned to bed, and without sleep rose again at half past six for the day. Attended the morning service at Dr Frothingham’s Church and heard him from Genesis 31.49. “And Mizpah; for he said, the Lord watch between me and thee, when we are absent one from another” On the final parting of Laban and Jacob—and by generalization, upon the final parting of Friends, one from another. The historical exposition of the transactions between Laban and Jacob, naturally fell into the subject of the discourse; but he did not dwell much upon that—but he commented well on the pathetic incidents of the separation— The heap of Stones, the Pillar—the Covenant—the appeal to God—the Heap of Witness (Galeed) and the Heap Witness (Mizpah) and the charge upon Jacob to take no other wives than Jacob’s daughters, were congenial to my views of the progress of civilization— The conclusion of Mr Frothingham’s discourse was exquisitely beautiful— There were two copies in Charles’s pew, one of which he gave to me of the Sermon preached last Sunday Morning, on All Saints day, and which has been printed— Returning from Meeting Mr George Bancroft passed by me in the crowd going out of the door. We barely recognized each other as we passed— I received a Letter from my wife, written at Washington, last Thursday. They arrived there, all safe, Wednesday Evening, after a pleasant journey [symbols] I wrote half a page of answer, and left it with Charles’s wife to finish, and send by the mail— We dined at one, and Charles then took me out to Quincy. He returned immediately to Boston, but I am to remain here till Tuesday Morning. Mr George W Beale called this evening with a subscription paper signed by Deacon Savil, Captain Josiah Bass and one other to call a parish meeting, to consider the expediency of raising the parish rates by taxing the pews. My parish taxes are about five times what they possibly could be if levied on the pews; but the tax would bear upon the poor by relieving the Landholders— I declined subscribing the paper, and said I was willing to bear a very disproportionate burden, to ease those who think themselves unable to bear any, and to keep peace and harmony in the church, which would certainly be disturbed by any attempt to change the mode of levying the tax— I wrote three short Letters this morning, and one this Evening: and gave the rest of the time to the reading of Sir George Staunton’s account of Lord Macartney’s abortive negotiation with the Chinese about the Ko Tow.— The Election excitement is at its highest pitch. Van Buren has carried Pennsylvania and Virginia, and has probably though not certainly lost New-York All is uncertainty here.
9. V. Monday.

Rain all night, and almost without intermission the whole of this day and evening— Elihu Thayer a native of Braintree, now residing in Quincy near Neponset Bridge, came to speak of a revolutionary pension claim of his mother Phebe, widow of Timothy Thayer— He says that the papers in support of the claim were sent by judge Leland, a year and a half ago to the Commissioner of Pensions from whom no answer has been received— I promised to make enquiry, and inform him of the result— I lost at least one half of this day in searching for the lease to Alpheus Spear of the Mount Wollaston farm, and for the manuscript of my version of the Psalms— I did not find the lease; but did find the manuscript, which is incomplete—the first 30 and five or six others not being included in the copy— I was so absorbed in this search, that the hour of Noon stole upon me before I was aware, and I had concluded to wait till after dinner before going to the town Hall to vote; but just before 1. J. J. Carr came, and urged me to go and vote immediately, for he feared that they would close the polls, before dinner— I went with him and took a printed ticket on which were the names of Governor; Lieutenant Governor, Senators for the County—Electors of President and Vice-President U.S. Representative for the 12th. Congressional District and Representative of the town in the State Legislature— My own name was on the list for Representative in Congress— I tore it off, and then tore from it the name of Mr Brown, for Representative of the Town— I then offered the two fragments of the ticket, which the Select-man declined receiving— I then said I should not vote at all; and they consented to receive my two papers pinned together. After dinner I went first to the Bank, and took up a check for 100 dollars— Then to Mr Lunt’s, but he was gone to Boston—next to Mr John Greenleaf’s, where I met C. P. Cranch andDawes and saw Mr and Mrs Greenleaf, both of whom are confined to their chamber, probably never to leave it— I returned to Mrs Greenleaf the two Letters from her father to Dr Eliot the biographer, and to Mrs Elizabeth Guild— She says she believes that the maiden name of the wife of John Norton the minister of Hingham was Mason— Mrs Greenleaf’s two daughters Lucy and Mary Dawes are living with her— My last visit was at Mrs T. B. Adams’s, but she went on Saturday to visit her daughter, Mrs Angier at Medford, and had not returned. Mrs Phineas Foster, Mrs Stebbins, and Elizabeth C Adams were there, and the midshipman John Quincy Adams, who is waiting for orders from the Secretary of the Navy— I came home just before Sunset, having trudged all the afternoon through the rain and over shoes in mire— Alpheus Spear was here almost the whole evening—talking about the renewal of his lease: and he paid me the parish tax of 1840. on the farm—

div.dateline: Quincy— Boston— Tuesday 10. November 1840. Waltham— Boston.
div.p: 10. V. Tuesday.

The rain continued the whole Night through, and from sultry warm as it was yesterday, the weather took the North-eastern chill— It held up this morning, and cleared off churlishly in the course of the day— Kirk brought me this morning a hand-bill; printed at Dedham, containing the election returns from the towns in the County of Norfolk, excepting Braintree— There never was an election so closely and so fiercely contested, but the whigs have carried the County Senators, which they lost last year. In the hurry of packing I was obliged again to leave my papers in extreme confusion, and had not time to write half the journal of yesterday.— I came into Boston in Gillet’s Omnibus. Sixteen inside passengers—among them, Mr Brown the Selectman and one of the Representatives of the town of the present year, but failed of reelection yesterday. Henry Wood was chosen by a majority of 5 votes— A man by the name of Jackson, a Plymouth, Kinderhoek and Abolitionist Spaniel, worked himself with the help of the Boston Customhouse in 1838. into a secret nomination against me, as Representative in Congress for the 12th. Congressional District.— It was then a secret mine, sprung upon me on the day of the election; wher until that day the Kinderhoek custom-house party had professed the intention to make no opposition to me. Since that time, Morton Jackson, with the aid of the Boston Custom-house, and Garrison’s abolitionists, has been working and worming himself into a nomination for the District, and attended, and pressed himself upon the Democratic convention which made the nomination—and yesterday at Quincy, outran me by 3 votes.— When I got to Charles’s house this morning Harriet Welsh soon came in, and borrowed for Mrs Lee, my Lecture upon Faith— Mr James Haley, President of the Mechanic Apprentice’s library Association came to say that they could not procure the Masonic Hall before next Monday. I promised to Lecture then, unless I should leave the City for Washington on that day. Dr George Parkman called, and I agreed to dine with him at half past 4. Mr Hubbard brought me a Letter from J. C. Brigham Corresponding Secretary of the American Bible Society, intreating me to attend and address a Meeting of the New-York City Auxiliary Bible Society which I declined, I fear in vain.— I called and afterwards dined at Mr Abbott Lawrence’s with a Mr Green, a Mr King—both of which have been recently in China, but whose opinions differ much as to the quarrel between Great Britain and China— At 5 O’Clock a Carriage came and took me up and at half past 6. I was at Waltham, at Dr Hobbes’s, and thence to Mr Ripley’s the Minister. Took coffee there, then returned to Dr Hobbes’s—and thence to the Meeting-house, where I delivered to the Adams Association, the lecture on civilization. Then to Dr Hobbes’s. Supper. Return alone to Charles’s house at Boston—half past 11.
11. V:30. Wednesday

The life I lead is trying to my Constitution, and cannot be long continued with impunity— Repose and regularity of hours and occupations, are essential to my health and to what remains of my capacity for useful labour— I live in continual bustle; a succession of Chinese Shadows, successive banqueting, late and early hours and political excitement and conflict, which stretches my old machine upon the rack— My eyes are threatening to fail me—my hands tremble like an aspen-leaf— My Memory daily deserts me—my imagination is fallen into the sear and yellow leaf, and my judgment sinking into dotage— The day before yesterday, my Son was elected one of 35 representatives of this City of Boston, in the Legislature of this Commonwealth— This is his first entrance into public Life, and may the blessing of God shield, and protect, and cheer and prosper him in this career— On the same day I was re-elected to represent the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts in the House of Representatives of the United States— Should my life and health be spared to perform this service, I shall have been the only representative of the District during the ten years of its existedce— I had represented in one Congress the preceding District of Plymouth— Before the next Election for Congress the Districts will be re-organized and new modelled; and then will be a proper time for me to withdraw, and take my last leave of the public service. This morning I went with Charles’s wife, and her daughter Louisa-Catherine, and visited Mrs Dexter, and Mrs King, widow of Edward King of Cincinnati, Ohio, and daughter of Thomas Worthington, with whom I sat five years in the Senate of the United States.— She has been residing several years at Cambridge, superintending the education of her two Sons and of three nephews, all of whom have now been graduated— Her Sons are now at Philadelphia, whither she proposes to remove, to finish their education, one for the Law and the other as a merchant. We next visited Mrs Amory, whom I once knew as Mehitable Sullivan; then as Mrs Cutler, afterwards wife of my classmate Jonathan Amory, and now his widow— She is now 70 years of age and I knew her at 16. She was then as she is now an example for her sex, living in health and competence with a promise of many more years more of respected age— Mrs Charles then left me to go to her Sister Mrs Frothingham’s, and I called to see my old friend Benjamin Pickman, whom I found with his daughter, and his Sons widow, daughter of my mothers cousin William Smith— I told Coll Pickman I had seen his Son, at Annapolis Nova-Scotia, but he said he was not there with his approbation. At half-past 4. I went and dined with Dr George Parkman— His brother, S. T. Armstrong, R. G. Shaw, Mr Chapman, the Mayor, and others—of the company— Home at 8—
12. V. Thursday—

North-east and South-east rainstorm, the whole day and evening through— But after journalizing for yesterday—I wasted the remainder of the morning. Mr Isaac Waters was one of the Appraisers appointed by President Monroe at my recommendation, when the Law of Congress authorizing those Officers was first enacted— He held the Office, till General Jackson came to the Presidency in 1829. and was then immediately dismissed. He came now to put in his claim for restoration—and to solicit my influence in his favour.— He could not have sought a more inefficient patron; but he announced his intention to go to Washington to the inauguration of General Harrison next March— I called soon after noon at the Secretary of the State’s Office, in the State house, and requested him when the Governor and Council shall meet to count the votes, and issue the credential of my election, to make out and send me a list of the votes returned from the 24 towns of the 12th. Congressional District; which he promised to do.— I visited also Mr. Felt’s room, and requested him to ascertain, if among the provincial records there is one of the grant of Lands to my ancestor Coll. John Quincy, in consideration of his public services.— Mr Felt promised that he would— He said Deacon William Spear had been with him, and spoken about the woodlot in Braintree, in which Mrs Felt and I have a joint interest— Just then Mr Lincoln a member of the State Senate came in, and we were obliged to suspend the conversation— I called at Dr Bigelow’s— He was not at home, but I saw Mrs Bigelow, and thanked her for the copy of the Memoir of Hannah Adams, which she gave to Harriet Welsh for me, and which I sent to Mrs M. Harrison Smith— I visited at Mr Sidney Brooks’s, but the house bell wire was broken, and I could not rouse a Servant to come to the door.— Dr Frothingham was not at home— I came back to Charles’s, and found Mr. Nathaniel Curtis waiting for me.— I went with him and my Son to Jamaica Plains Roxbury, and dined with him at his house. Mrs Boylston and her two grandsons, Ward Nicholas and Thomas, sons of John Lane Boylston were there— Mrs Curtis, their Son and his wife, and General, and Mrs William H. Sumner, also.— General Sumner had invited me to tea, and to pass the Night at his house— I accepted the first part of the invitation; but had engaged to return this Evening to Boston. At General Sumner’s, we met Dr Thomas Gray, and Mr George Whitney Ministers of the Congregational church, at Jamaica-Plains, and a young man by the name of Cleveland— At 7 in the Evening we went to the Jamaica Plains Meeting house, where I delivered the Lecture upon Faith— Mr George Whitney announced another Lecture for next Tuesday Evening.— The Auditory was small, for it poured with rain the whole Evening.— The house was badly lighted— My dinner, and coffee and milk, had affected my voice and my eye-sight, painfully, and I got through my Discourse as I could.— Immediately after which, Mr Curtis’s Carriage took me with my Son back to his house at Boston.
13. IV. Friday.

After a storm of ten days duration, floods upon floods of rain, and alternations of chilly and sultry atmosphere, the sky took this day to clear up.— I resumed the writing of an Article upon the quarrel between Great Britain and China, but made slow and very little progress in it. Miss Harriet Welsh came with her nephew Thomas Welsh who gave me a Letter to the Secretary of the Navy soliciting the appointment of an assistant Surgeon in the Navy.— With it there is a certificate from Dr Jacob Bigelow that Thomas Welsh has studied medicine under his tuition one year and upwards; attended Lectures and hospital practice, and borne a good character— The certificate is also signed by D. Humphreys Storer and Edward Reynolds— Withal, a Letter to me soliciting my assistance to obtain the appointment, which I promised— Call at Charles’s Office, where I saw Mr Spooner, and signed powers to Charles to receive dividends on Mercantile Insurance company and Providence Rail-road Stock— Then at Loring’s 122 State-Street, to examine a patent Perryian filter inkstand advertised for sale, but of which except two of the smallest size there were none left— Met Dr W. P. Greenwood there— Call to see Mr. William Foster at his lodgings Mrs Le Kain’s, Summer Street— Not at home—then next door at Sidney Brooks’s— Bell-wire not repaired— At Dr Frothingham’s— He was to have dined with Charles to day; but was confined to his chamber, unwell, and sent an excuse— He appeared to be depressed in Spirits.— Dr Thomas Gray brought me copies of my versions of the 23d and 104th. Psalms, which I had given him, and yesterday requested him to lend me for the use of Mr Lunt: I gave them to him in 1831— He brought also a leaf of a new hymn book, which has been recently compiled, and published by him for the use of his church, and in which 5. Stanzas of my lines on the death of Mrs Ann Hellen’s two infant children, are inserted as a hymn, on the death of an infant.— Dr Gray said that on losing an infant grandchild he had found exquisite comfort in those lines— May I be forgiven, for the joy which this saying gave me. Mr James Haley, President of the Mechanic Apprentices Library Association, came to enquire, if I could deliver a Lecture for them next Monday— I told him I should be under the necessity of leaving the City on that day— He thanked me in the name of the Society for what I had done for them; and I promised to send him Congressional Documents for them, as I had done to their President James L. Curry last year— Edward Brooks, Isaac P. Davis, Samuel K. Lathrop, William Minot, John G. Palfrey, and Josiah Quincy junr. dined with Charles this day—and we had a jovial time from 4 to 9. P.M.
14. IV. Saturday.

Mr Samuel Lawrence with Mr Edwards and another person whom I did not know came this morning to enquire if I thought the bill for the more effectual collection of the revenue would be resumed at the approaching session of Congress.— I said I thought it would not; I believed that the policy of the expiring administration would be to diminish rather than increase the revenue— Mr Edwards was well satisfied that the bill as it was returned last Summer from the Senate did not pass, though that was not Mr Lawrence’s impression at that time— I had made an appointment yesterday with Isaac P. Davis to go with him this day at Noon to go, and see an Original Venus of Titian, but I forgot the appointment, and, and paid a long morning visit to Dr William Ellery Channing. We conversed much upon European and foreign politics, but not upon our own. The Doctor thinks that Peace has become such an overruling principle of policy in the popular feeling of all Christian Nations, that there is little or no present danger of War— I did not altogether concur in this opinion, but thought the war fever running very high, especially in France— After I returned to Charles’s, Dr George Parkman, Mr Richard Fletcher, and Louisa C. Smith successively called to see me— Mr Peter C. Brooks, dined with us at Charles’s, and immediately after dinner—Charles brought me out to Quincy— It was pitch dark when we got out, between 6 and 7 O’Clock in the Evening, and he quite unexpectedly to me returned immediately to Boston— I sent John Kirk to Mr Lunt with a request that he would come to me, and he immediately came— I gave him the manuscript copy of the first thirty Psalms of my version; with the two which Dr Gray had lent me, and the leaf from the hymn book containing the lines on the death of an infant and the version of thechapter of Isaiah— I told him that he might select all or any of my psalms for his compilation at his pleasure— And that if he could find it for his own interest to publish the whole book of the Psalms, I asked his acceptance of the copy-right— He thanked me, without expressly accepting my offer; and said that in the manuscript that I had sent him there were passages which would require my revisal— In fact the copies never were collated with my first draughts. He enquired if my version was not all in one measure. Most of it is in the 8 lined Stanza, of 8 syllabled alternate rhymes— But some are in the 8 and 6 line and some in the six line measure— Mr Lunt left me after 9. I could write but little.
15. IV:30. Sunday.

Rain all night and all this morning.— I had intended to remain at Quincy till after the second service; but hearing from Mr Lunt last Night, that he was not to preach, himself, I concluded to come to Boston in time to hear Dr Frothingham, half the day.— John Kirk brought me in, in the Carriage. I found Mr William Minot, visiting my Son— After dinner, I went with Charles and his two elder Sons to Meeting and heard Dr Frothingham, from Philippians 2.4— “Look not every man on his own things, but every man also on the things of others.”

The subject fell in remarkably with a part of my Lecture upon Faith, and contains many of the same thoughts— The duty of caring for others as well as for ourselves was expounded in a very eloquent style.— After Meeting I went with Mrs Charles and visited Mr and Mrs Carey— This Lady is the daughter of Mrs Charles Paine’s and she was an daughter of my fathers friend and classmate Charles Cushing, some time Clerk of the Supreme Court of the Commonwealth. Mrs Paine was one of three daughters of Mr Cushing, who formed part of the Society frequented by me in Boston from 1790 to 1794— Charles Paine, third son of judge Robert Treat Paine, was then perhaps in College.— I was then seven years absent in Europe— On my return I found Charles Paine a young lawyer of considerable promise—married I think to this Lady; but in my short residences at Boston from 1801. to 1809. I remember not to have met or seen her— Since then I have not resided in Boston, nor seen Mrs Paine— Her husband died young. Mrs Carey is her daughter, with whom she lives— Mrs Carey has three sons, the eldest of whom, is about 15. and a daughter, a playmate, of my granddaughter Louisa-Catherine, and about of her age— Mrs Paine was very handsome in her youth, and is so yet, for her years— We went next to Mr Edward Brooks’s, to tea, and my glass of milk— Mrs Brooks was a Boott— Their eldest son about 18. six feet four inches tall, has just returned from Edinburgh from his studies. Abby positively forbade him to call her, Aunt— Mrs Brooks asked me for an autograph of my father which I promised.— After tea, I returned home with Abby, and there found Gorham Brooks who has resided several years in Baltimore, but has now returned to Boston.— Mr Peter C. Brooks soon after came in, and Mr Degrand— We were engaged to spend the Evening at Mr Josiah Quincy junrs— But Charles was suffering with one of his severe headaches, and could not go— Abby insisted upon her father’s going with us to Mr Quincy’s and he indulged her— We found at Mr Quincy’s Isaac P. Davis, William Minot—Mr and Mrs Green, and Horace Mann— Pleasant Evening— Petit Soupé. Stewed Oysters. Home at ten— I concluded to take only one trunk, which Abby packed for me. I leave two here.
16. V. Monday.

I rose at five— Abby and her son John Quincy were up— Charles was sleeping off his headache and I desired he might not be awaked— I breakfasted and parted from my children commending them to the care of a kind Providence— At 1/2 past 6 the hack that Charles had ordered came to Hancock Avenue N. 3.— Charles’s Irish Man servant Edward accompanied me, to the depot of the Worcester and Springfield Rail-road— There I found Josiah Quincy junr. going to Worcester. He is the Treasurer of this company, and President of the Providence Rail-road. He introduced me to the Son and daughter of Mr Nathan Appleton, who with another Lady were going to Springfield— At 7. the Cars started— There had been a sharp frost and it was bitter cold— But the Sun rose clear, and the day was fine— The first stop was Framingham.— The second at Westborough, and at each of them was a horse shoe table, with Coffee-grounds, cold tea, and stale gingerbread for such as chose to snatch a breakfast— At the Westborough Station I met Dr Palfrey who was in the Worcester Car—going to see a child he has there— About 10. we stopped about ten minutes, and then proceeded through Brookfield and Warren to Springfield where we arrived at 1/2 past one, and found the worst dinner that has fallen to my lot for many years— At Springfield, a letter was delivered to me from George G. Spencer informing me that he would be ready to receive me at Hartford and recommending to me to lodge at the City Hotel— At Springfield 96 miles from Boston the Rail-way terminates— Thence we came in a Stage 28 Miles to Hartford where we arrived a quarter before 6— In the Stage I had two travelling companions, one from Maine and one from Kentucky—the latter with two ladies.— They tempted me to talk more than Prudence would warrant as often happens to me from the vanity of hearing myself talk— At the City Hotel, I found Mr Joseph Trumbull, the member of Congress, and Mr Spencer who had given me the invitation from the young men’s institute to deliver the Lecture— I sent for a barber, who shaved me at my chamber— Meanwhile Governor W. W. Ellsworth came in, with two or three other Gentlemen, and accompanied me to the presbyterian Church where I delivered the Lecture on Faith— The house was crowded— The pulpit whence I spoke indifferently lighted— My head swimming, after a chilly day, a ride of 120 miles, in Rail-way Cars and Stages, and since breakfast a very scanty meal— But this I believe carried me through— The audience were deeply attentive, and manifested no impatience— Many came up after it was over, and shook hands with me, among whom were judge Williams, and Mr Wadsworth, a Son of Coll. Jeremiah Wadsworth, at whose house I dined in August 1785— Governor Ellsworth returned with me to my lodgings, where after a very light refreshment of a cracker and cheese, and a glass of water, at 1/2 past 9 I retired to bed—
17. IV.45 Tuesday—

At 1/2 past 5. A.M. I took the Cars from Hartford to New-Haven. My tavern bill, at Hartford had been paid— The Night had been frosty; and the morning was bitter cold— But the Sun rose bright and the whole day was fair— In the cars two passengers introduced themselves to me—Mr Hopkins of Buffalo New-York, and Mr Curtis, Sheriff of the County of New-Haven— I talked again too much. At 8 A.M. we arrived at New-Haven, and I took lodgings at the Tontine Hotel— Breakfast— Immediately after, Mr Roger Sherman Baldwin called on me, and invited me to his office in his house, whither I went with him— He read to me sundry papers, and gave me one containing an argument, drawn up, by him all, relating to the Negro-prisoners taken in the Amistad— We had two hours of conversation upon the whole subject, in which he exposed to me his views of the case; the points which had been taken before the District and Circuit Courts; and the motion to dismiss the appeal which he supposes the proper course to be taken before the Supreme Court— He read to me numerous authorities on the several points which he proposes to urge at the trial; and said he hoped the Supreme Court would take up the case in the first or second week of the Session.— I visited the prisoners, with Mr Baldwin— Mr Wilcox the Marshal of the District— Mr Pendleton, his deputy, and keeper of the house where they are confined together— The three girls are in a separate house, and I did not see them— There are 36 men, confined all in one chamber perhaps 30 feet long by 20 wide—sleeping in 18 crib beds in rows two deep on both sides the length of the chamber— They are all but one young men, under 30. and of small stature—none over 5 feet 6. Negro-face, fleece and form—but varying in shades of colour from ebon black to dingy brown— One or two of them are almost mulatto bright. Cinque and Grabow, the two chief conspirators, have very remarkable countenances— Three of them read to us part of a chapter in the English New Testament— Very indifferently— One boy writes a tolerable hand— Mr Ludlow teaches them; but huddled together as they are, and having no other person to talk with but themselves their learning must be very slow— I dined at Mr Baldwin’s, with 8 or 10 others— Mrs Baldwin’s is a daughter of old Roger Sherman— Her mother, and brother, Mr Baldwin’s father, Chauncey Goodrich and Mr Ludlow were of the company. President Day Professor Kingsley and Professor Silliman came in after dinner— I walked with Professor Silliman to his house, to tea—His wife, Son, 3 daughters—one married.— Coll. John Trumbull—this day from New-York— born in 1756.—very unwell—said he was done up—worn out.— With Dr Silliman I visited Mrs Gerry—her 4. daughters— Went with Mr White to Mr Ludlow’s Church— Delivered the Lecture on Society and civilization— Full house. Attention— Applause— Home to my lodgings at 9. P.M.
18. IV. Wednesday.

I wrote 3 hours this morning before breakfast with practical experience of the due employment of time. The loss of these Morning hours is too often unavoidable in travel, and made so yet more frequently by indolence and sluggishness— As I came down to breakfast a young man named William E. Robinson introduced himself to me, and asked me for my autograph signature, which I entered upon his book— He said he was a native of Ireland, now a Student in the Senior Class at New-Haven. He was over-officious in his attentions, which I attributed to good motives, and he accompanied me to the Steamer New-Haven which at 8. cast off from the wharf for New-York— On board the boat, was another Student of Yale-College, named Hoffman, a Nephew of Ogden Hoffman, of the junior Class.— He was a fellow passenger with me in the boat— Robinson introduced him to me; and specially recommended me to his attentions— Hoffman, a very well bred youth, without being intrusive, did shew me every kind attention that he could have shewn to his father— He told me that Robinson was a great politician, and an ardent whig; and that during the canvas for the recent election, he had gone round many of the towns in the neighbourhood, and addressed the People in favour of Harrison— Our passage to New-York, 90 miles was easy, but the atmosphere was full of snow, and too chilly to keep the deck— About 11. O’Clock it began to snow, with a light breeze from the South-west, which soon changed to the North-east and freshened— Driven down into the cabin my yesterday’s fellow traveller from Kentucky drew me again into a political conversation more verbose than discreet.— There was among the passengers a whig member of Congress elect from Pennsylvania; in the place of M’Cullough— We reached the wharf at New-York at 2. O’Clock P.M. and after half an hour of detention amid the shipping to get along-side the wharf, and a fisticuff battle between a hackman and a Steamer-man, young Hoffman procured me a Hack, with which I came to the Astor-house. Met there Isaac T. Smith and Dr John H. Griscom, with whom I agreed to the arrangements for this Evening’s Lecture. Dined at the Ladies Ordinary, with Mr and Mrs Downing who are lodging at the Astor-House— Numerous visitors after dinner. Josiah Quincy junr. Sidney Brooks, Alexander S. Johnson—Coll. William L. Stone, and other visitors till 7. J. L. Brigham, A. B. Baylis and James M’Lean, lecture Committee of Arrangements of Hamilton Literary Association at Brooklyn for a Lecture there to-morrow. Mr Russell invites me to a Log-cabin and Tippecanoe Ball to-morrow— J. S. Marchant— Painter— At the Tabernacle— Delivered Lecture on Society and Civilization— Mrs De Wint, Lewis Tappan. Party at Charles Augustus Davis’s—Alvear—Rosas—Davezac—Mr and Mrs Sidney Brooks—Mr and Mrs Jonathan Amory— Home in a Cab after Midnight
19. VII. Thursday.

Besides the names in the margin sundry other visitors called on me this day in such succession that it was impossible for me to remember them. I breakfasted with Mr and Mrs Downing at the Ladies ordinary, and immediately after, Mrs De Wint with her daughter Anna Maria came in— Mr and Mrs Whittemore are also in the City, and Julia De Wint, but according to their usual custom dispersed about among their friends in different parts of the City— Dr Griscom President of the New York Lyceum came and urgently solicited me to stay here over to-morrow, and to delive at the Tabernacle the same Lecture which I had determined to deliver, this Evening at Brooklyn— He said it would purchase at least 500 volumes of books for the Library— After some hesitation I consented to stay; doubtful of my own discretion, but hoping that my motive was good— I had parted yesterday from Mr Marchant, with the understanding that as I was to be here only this day, and could give him only one sitting he had given up the purpose of painting my portrait— After concluding to stay till Saturday, I went to Mr Marchant’s and told him I could sit this day and to-morrow, if it should suit him, and accordingly I sat nearly two hours before, and one after dinner— Mr Frelinghuysen invited me to dine with him tomorrow— Mr W. B. Lawrence told me that Mr Gallatin was just publishing a pamphlet on the North-eastern boundary question— A retort upon that of Featherstonhaugh— Mr Tappan who came with Mr Leavitt gave me a pamphlet concerning the case of the Amistad Negroes. Mr Appleton and Mr Quincy departed for Boston. About 6 P.M. Mr Baylis and Mr M’Lean Committee of the Brooklyn Society came with a hack came and took me over to the town hall, where I was received with some formality by the Mayor and Aldermen— Met there the Revd. Dr Cox of the Presbyterian Church— After suitable introductions and shaking of hands, we proceeded to the Church, where I delivered to a crowded auditory the Lecture on Faith, which was well received— After another hour of handshaking, I went to the Log Cabin Tippecanoe Ball— Dr. Coxe accompanied me to the door and there took leave. After a short stay there, Mr Baylis and Mr M’Lean accompanied me back to my lodgings at the Astor house, New-York— I received from Dr. Griscom a volume recently published by him upon animal mechanism.
20. VI:30. Friday.

Chaos of confusion— With visitors, many of whom, strangers whom I never saw before, and never shall see again. Scarcely able to make minutes of the passage of time. After breakfast sat 2 hours to Mr Marchant—who has taken a good likeness though the portrait is unfinished— He requested of me a line of recommendation to Mr Gallatin whose portrait he is very desirous of taking. He has those of General Jackson, General Harrison, Henry Clay, Mr Ewing of Ohio, Chancellor James Kent and some others— Mrs Marchant and her sister, both comely women came in and joined in conversation while he was at work. At noon I went with Mrs De Wint, and Mr and Mrs Downing to the house of the late Mr Luman Reed whose collection of pictures is still kept by his widow and family. His daughter only was now there and received the Ladies— The pictures are chiefly by Cole and Durand who is now in Europe— There is an excellent portrait of Mr Reed by him; a copy of Carlo Dolce’s Saint Cecilia, and light, humorous fancy pieces on the pannels of the doors. Five large pictures, representing the course of Empire by Cole, are more remarkable for the design than for the execution—much of both are borrowed from Claude— There is one picture of the hunter state—one of the pastoral and agricultural state, for each of which there should be one, and three for the splendour, the decline, and the ruin of a magnificent city— They are pleasing and striking pictures— The first seven Presidents of the United States are ranged in their order—myself and Jackson painted by Durand; and the rest good copies by him from Stuart— Returned to the Astor house and took leave of Mrs De Wint, and Mr and Mrs Downing— The latter return this Evening to Newburg.— Mrs De Wint told me she liked my lecture on Faith, better than the other— And she asked why Charles did not substitute the portrait of my mother engraved from Stuarts Portrait, in the new Edition of the Letters, instead of the other which gives great dissatisfaction— With Mr B. J. Silliman and Ogden Hoffman I went to the City Library, of 25000 volumes. Then to the custom house where Mr Jesse Hoyt the Collector repeated his opinion of the urgent necessity for the Bill to suppress frauds on the revenue, which failed at the last Session of Congress. I had received a Letter from Mr Hoyt requesting to see me. Mr W. Ratcliff called also, but I could barely see him for a moment—from 3. to 5 I went twice in a Cab to N 23 and 25 Washington Square and back without finding Mr Frelinghuysen— Fragment dinner at the Astor house. Mr Shaw a Candidate for the Chaplaincy of the Senate— Hart— To see him at 6. to-morrow Morning. Alexander S. Johnson— Lecture on Faith at the Tabernacle Supper at Sidney Brooks’s chamber, with Mr and Mrs C. A. Davis and Coll William L. Stone— Packed my trunk at Midnight.
21. V. Saturday.

Mr Hart from 150 to 200 miles beyond Louisville in Kentucky; with a recommendation from Mr Frelinghuysen applied to me at 6. O Clock this morning to deliver a Lecture at Philadelphia, and another at Baltimore, for the benefit of a protestant school at his residence in Kentucky, in opposition to a Roman Catholic school, which is gaining proselytes, and if suffered to continue with convert all Kentucky.— Fudge! I told him that from his statement it appeared there was sectarian competition and jealousy in this case: that I must at all events abstain from interference in it— I was aware of the proselyting spirit of the Roman Catholics; but I thought it in this Country sufficiently controuled by the combined influence of so many other Christian sects against it— I believed the prejudice against them in my own section of the Country, excessive, as had been proved by the destruction of the Convent at Charlestown; and I should be glad rather to mitigate than to exasperate the feeling against them; as I thought them rather a persecuted sect— But that if I were ever so well disposed to the object of his solicitation, I should not now have time to comply with it— He argued the case till I was in danger, of losing my temper—but I refrained— He departed without much sulky comment— On application at the Bar for my Bill I was informed that it had been paid last evening by Mr I. T. Smith— He and Dr Griscom came, and accompanied me to the Steamer Independence for Amboy. They were profuse in professions of gratitude for the service which they said I had rendered to their Institution, and said they could not forbear to offer me some portion of their profits— They neither said what those profits were; nor what portion of them they proposed to offer me— I said that I wished them to apply whatever they proposed to offer me as a donation from me to the purposes of the Society— The only fellow passenger to Philadelphia whom I knew was Charles F. Mitchell the member H.R.U.S. from New-York—but a Mr Tilson from Quincy, Illinois, another person from Philadelphia, and one from Baltimore, claimed former introductions to me, and entertained conversations with me. our course as usual, was in the Steamer to the landing at Amboy: then in the rail-way Cars to Bordentown— Then in the Steamer New-Philadelphia to the Chesnut Street wharf where we landed at 1/2 past 2. P.M. I walked to the Union Hotel in that Street, kept by Mr Jones, met on my way Mrs John Sergeant, and G. W. Toland the member. H.R.U.S.— I called at Mr Nicholas Biddle’s and at John Sergeant’s—neither of them at home— Second call at Sergeant’s. Found H. A. Wise there; just recovered from a severe bilious fever. To be married next Thursday to Sergeant’s third daughter—Sarah— N. Biddle soon came in, and took me with him to the Wistar party at Thomas Biddle’s where were assembled between 50 and 60 persons—among whom were Mr Peter the British Consul—The President of the Girard College Bache—Commodore Reed—John Vaughn, Dr Chapman, W. B. Reed, Charles F Mercer—Gerrit Smith, judge Hopkinson, H. Middleton, cum multis aliis— Supper. Home at 11. P.M— Mr Middleton is a fellow lodger.
22. V. Sunday.

I was able this morning to write for a couple of hours before breakfast. Met at the breakfast table Mr Charles Fenton Mercer who after 22 years of service in the house of representatives of the United States, last Winter in a fit of despair accepted an Office as Cashier of a Bank at Tallahassee in Florida; and is now going to England I suppose to raise the wind for that institution. Mercer is one of the most respectable natives of Virginia, and has devoted his life to the internal improvement of the Country, and to the gradual extinction of Slavery in the State— In both of these benevolent and exalted purposes his exertions have been abortive— The Savage and barbarous genius of Slavery has not only baffled them all, but has kindled a flame of popular odium against him, from which he has shrunk into the cashier of a bank at Tallahassee— A noble Spirit doomed to drudge in the mines! I called at Mr John Sergeants and walked with him and Mrs Sergeant to the Episcopal Church where Mr Odenheimer read the morning service for the 23d Sunday after Trinity, and preached from Ephesians 6.17. “And take the helmet of Salvation”—he observed that there was some obscurity in the text as to what the helmet of Salvation was: but that from another text 1. Thessalonians 5.8. it was ascertained to be Hope; and thus opened the general subject of all the encouragements of religion— The discourse was apparently one of a series, upon the several weapons of the whole armour of God— The preacher is a young man moderately eloquent, and his amplification of the virtue and efficacy of Hope as a Christian virtue was instructive and might have been specially useful to me— Particularly his quotation from St. Paul, who had hope, because he had fought the good fight; and had kept the faith— As I was coming out of church Mrs. Middleton spoke and named herself to me. I had not seen her for more than twenty years— She had then several young children, but was young and beautiful— Now she has the remains of beauty blended with the marks of deep affliction upon her face— I should not have recognized her She is English born, and bears an excellent character— I dined with Mr N. Biddle, en famille, with no other addition save judge Hopkinson.— We sat after dinner, settling the Nation till near 8 in the Evening, little satisfied with the result— Hopkinson is snug in port. Content with his office of District judge— Undisturbed by Ambition or fear.— Biddle broods with smiling face and stifled groans over the wreck of splendid, blasted expectations, and ruined hopes. A fair mind—a brilliant genius, a generous temper an honest heart, waylaid and led astray by prosperity—suffering the penalty of scarcely voluntary error—tis piteous to behold.— The judge accompanied me to my lodgings. Dr. Mitchell called; and Mr Connell and Mr Middleton successively came in, and I passed the remainder of the Evening till near midnight with them— Connell has again been unfortunate, and told me he should be under the necessity of applying to General Harrison for an Office— This worthy man’s ups and downs in life have been numerous and lamentable— Mr Middleton resides in Summer at Newport R.I. and as winter approaches takes his flight to the South—
23. V. Monday.

Rose at 5 O’Clock, and answered the Letter of Coll. John Miles, received last Evening, inviting me by direction of the commanding General of the division, (I know not who he is,[)] to be present at the solemnities on the occasion of the removal of the remains of General Hug Mercer of the Revolutionary Army, on Thursday 26th. of November instt—with a notification that the Governors of New-Jersey, Pennsylvania, and Virginia are expected to be present—and that a special Committee would wait upon me at 1/2 past 9 at my residence—and with a request for an answer to the Letter— I declined the invitation under the necessity of returning immediately to Washington to join my family— I had not time to take a copy of my Letter— I had last evening verbally answered and declined a similar invitation, from the St. Andrew’s Society of Philadelphia, enclosed to me, by Dr J. K. Mitchell, who informed me that the same invitation had been addressed to me at Quincy, which I have not received— Dr. Mitchell made me also a present of a small volume of Poems, recently published by him—with a dedication in the Scottish dialect to Doctor Chapman.— I received also last Evening a Letter fromLeity with an invitation to deliver a Lecture, to morrow evening before the William Wirt literary institute, which I had not time to answer.— I had intended to go to Baltimore in the Steamboat line, but it was last week discontinued.— I walked to the rail-road depot in market Street where I found Mr John Connell waiting to take leave of me— At 8. O’Clock the train started, drawn by four horses about 3 miles; then linked to the locomotive which brought us to Fell’s point at Baltimore a quarter past 2. when four horses were again tackled to the Cars and landed us at 1/2 past 2. at the depot in Pratt Street— Mr and Mrs Henry Middleton of Charleston South-Carolina, with a Son G. W. a daughter, and a boy and girl, grand children 11 or 12 years old were fellow passengers in the cars; with only one attendant white woman.— They have been passing the Summer at Newport, and are returning to Charleston but stop this Night at Baltimore— I had just time to dine upon the leavings of a dinner table at the Eagle tavern opposite the depot, where I met Mr W. Hunter; the assistant doorkeeper of H.R.U.S.— At 4 P.M. started again with the horses soon exchanged for the engine— Mr Davezac of New-Orleans, and Mr H. Legare, of Charleston S.C. were fellow passengers in these Cars— Reached the depot at a quarter past 6. at Washington; where I found Jeremy Leary waiting for me; ready for me with a hack which brought me before 7. to my wife, and daughter and granddaughter—all well [symbols]
24. V. Tuesday.

I received soon after my arrival last Evening, a Note from Mr J. H. Lowden, styling himself of Charleston, and as representing the heirs of Commodore Paul Jones, of Revolutionary War renown requesting an interview with me— I answered the Note early this morning, and appointed any time between 10 and 12 to receive him. He came accordingly, with a reprinted copy of Document N. 19. H.R.U.S. 24. Congress 2. Session. a Memorial of Janette Taylor for herself and the other representatives of John Paul Jones, dated 12. December 1836. and then referred to the Committee on Revolutionary Claims.— No report was made by that Committee on the case; but at the special Session in 1837. Mr Caleb Cushing reported from the Committee of Foreign Affairs a Resolution requesting the President to negotiate with the Danish Government in behalf of the claim.— There was no action of the House upon this Resolution— But there was a report of the present Secretary of State John Forsyth upon a Resolution of the Senate of 1. Feby 1836. referring to him the Memorial of Janette Taylor, to that body. Mr Lowden shewed me now a Letter to the Secretary of State, enquiring if he had any further information of the condition of the claim— And he asked my advice whether it would be proper for him to address this Letter to the Secretary— I told him I saw no objection to it; nor to his calling personally on the Secretary of State, and conversing with him on the subject. This evening I received another Letter from Mr Lowden stating the result of his conversation with Mr Forsyth; and sending the printed copy of the house Document N. 19 and a Manuscript copy of Forsyth’s Report to the Senate in 1836. with a request in flattering terms that I would take charge of the advocacy of the claim in the house; and closing with a notice that he should leave the city to-morrow— Mr Lowden appears to be a Scotchman of education and gentlemanly deportment; but he has an impediment in his speech, which makes it painful to converse with him— Mrs W. S. Smith now living with her brother T. B. Johnson was here, and also Mary Cutts; and Mrs Stuart, whom I did not see, but who read to my wife, a Letter from her daughter Mrs Parnell, in Ireland— I called at Mr T. B. Johnson’s house to see him but he was riding out— I then walked to the Capitol, took out from the Library, nine volumes of different works relating to China; found that R. W. Habersham had taken the Seat in the House which had been Mr Abbott Lawrence’s at the last Session, and my name on the table which was Rice Garland’s, and which he had transferred to me at the close of the Session— I bespoke some Stationary, and a packet of Newspapers which were lying for me at the Post-Office. I then came home, and spent the remainder of the day and Evening in reading my Letters and papers, and in Auber’s China, published in 1834. and in journalizing till 10. P.M.
25. IV:30. Wednesday.

Rain again, the whole day long. Morning visits from Dr Sewall, and from Mr Hodgson, who, since the close of the last Session of Congress has been to Europe as a bearer of despatches, and has just returned, in the British Queen, which arrived at New-York last Saturday. Mr Hodgson carried out to Berlin a Treaty negotiated there by Mr Wheaton, with the Minister of the king of Hanover—between the United States, and Hanover— It was ratified by and with the advice and consent of the Senate of the United States at their last Session. The Treaty was sent by Mr Hodgson for exchange of ratifications, but it was drawn up in the English and French Languages, and his Hanoverian Majesty declines exchanging the ratifications, unless upon an agreement that the French text shall be declared the original Treaty— Mr Hodgson returns therefore, without the Hanoverian Ratification— I walked to the Capitol and called at the Clerk’s Office— The Documents and Journals of the last Session have not yet been received from the Bookbinders. I exchanged an Inkstand The Books which I took yesterday out from the Library are 1. Henry Ellis’s journal of the proceedings of Lord Amherst’s embassy to China in 1816. An Edition published at Philadelphia in 1818. 2. Notices relating to China, by Sir George Thomas Staunton Bart. published in 1822 3. British Relations with the Empire of China in 1832, An anonymous pamphlet. 4. China—by Peter Auber. 1834. 5. The Fan-Qui in China in 1836–7. by Toogood Downing, in 3. Volumes. 1838. 6. China opened—by the Revd. Charles Gutzlaff—revised by the Revd. Andrew Reed D.D. 2. Volumes 1838.— All these books are necessary to enable me to do any thing like justice to the Article on the quarrel between Great-Britain and China, which I am preparing for Dr Palfrey, and I brought with me four small volumes of the Library of entertaining knowledge—entitled the Chinese—by John Francis Davis—published in 1837— After writing as long as I was able, I devoted this evening to reading Ellis’s journal of the proceedings of Lord Amherst’s embassy in 1816, which was much more cavalierly treated than that of Lord Macartney in 1793— Many of the same formalities were indeed observed, but with Lord Amherst, the whole negotiation was confined to the discussion whether the Embassador would or would not perform the prostration of the Ko-Tou, and as soon as it was found that he would not he was turned off without being admitted to the presence of the Emperor— It is plain that the moment that pretension shall be broken down, China will be open to foreign commerce and foreign travel— The Chinese Mandarins maintained that Lord Macartney did perform the Ko-Tou before the Emperor Kien Long; and they told Lord Amherst that if he would perform the ceremony he might make what report of it to his Government he pleased!—
26. IV:30. Thursday—

Mr Ousely the gardener at the President’s house came this morning to confide to me his grievances and his apprehensions— Nolan, the Commissioner of the Public buildings employs a gardener at the Capitol where there is nothing to do, but to keep the grounds clean and gives him a Salary of 1200 dollars a year—a job for a partizan— The man’s name is Mar— While Ousely himself, an excellent gardener and man, who raises all the vegetables and much fruit for the Presidents house, is allowed only 450 dollars a year, and a workman to assist him less than six weeks of the time— Ousely thinks it probable that Mar will be dismissed, and that the two gardeners should be placed on an equal footing; and the Salary equally divided between them— Long morning visit from Coll. Thomas, but he had now nothing new to tell. I paid a morning visit to the President— Met in the large entry below coming out as I went in Mr Levi Woodbury, the Secretary of the Treasury, with a Lady whom he named as Mrs Hale of Boston— I found with the President, in his cabinet, his Son Abram and Mr Joel R. Poinsett, Secretary of War. Our conversation was altogether upon European Affairs, chiefly of France, which the President thinks in a dilemma, between external war, and internal revolution. My next call was upon Mr James K. Paulding, Secretary of the Navy, to whom I made the application in behalf of Thomas Welsh, for the appointment of Surgeon’s mate in the Navy. Mr Paulding said his name would be placed on the register, and that he would have to undergo an examination— I went thence to Mr T. B. Johnson’s and sat half an hour with him. He has had since we left the City last July a very severe paralytic attack, and his life hangs upon the most attenuated of Spider’s threads— The physicians who have attended him assure his Sisters that his mental faculties are not impaired, which is scarcely credible; but he has sufficiently the use of his limbs to walk about his chamber and to write his name— I gave him on my Son’s account and at his request a check for 50 dollars, of which he said he would acknowledge the receipt in a Letter to Charles— Thence on a visit to the General Post-Office, I requested of Mr John M. Niles the Postmaster General, a copy of the Petition upon which Luther Angier was removed from the Office of Postmaster at Medford— I had received a Letter from Mr John Angier, asking me to apply for this copy— Mr Niles shewed me the petition, signed by nine persons, but declined furnishing a copy of it, which he said was contrary to a long standing rule of the office— While I was out Mr Frye was here, and I received Evening visits from Mr Albion K. Parris, my next door neighbour and Tenant; with his father—from W. P. Elliot a Clerk in the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions; and from the Revd. Mr Hawley. Elliot shewed me a notification from the Commissioner of Pensions J. L Edwards that his services would be no longer needed after next February.
27. IV. Friday.

Cleared away, cold. Mr M’Cormick is a native of Ireland; a Clergyman of the Episcopal Church, and when I first came to Washington as a member of the Senate in 1803. was settled as Minister of a small, poor church at the Navy-Yard— On the 1st. of January 1818 I appointed him a Clerk in the Department of State; an Office which he yet holds, having been promoted from a Salary of 1000 to one of 1450 dollars a year. He remembers me, and at the commencement of a Session of Congress visits me when he can do it without danger.— Mr Harris is a young man, President of the Mercantile Library Association at Baltimore. He brought me a Letter from David Hoffman, earnestly urging me to deliver one of my Lectures, before that institution next Tuesday Evening; and I promised if no accident before that time should intervene to prevent me, that I would—and that in the event of such accident I would give notice of it to Mr Harris, if there should be time. Morning visit from Dr Thomas— I asked him what was the true condition of Mr T. B. Johnsons health and mind— He said he was hypochondriac and had no other disease— None for which a physician could prescribe— He was whimsical, and flighty, but not of unsound mind— I called on the Secretary of the Treasury at the Department, and conversed with him concerning the Letter I had received from Jesse Hoyt the Collector at New-York and my interview with him at the Custom house there relating to the Bill for suppressing frauds on the revenue, which was lost at the last Session of Congress. Mr Woodbury thought the Bill, which had first passed the house of more importance now, than the superfetation from the Senate.— He said he should be prepared to report upon a revisal of the Tariff, if Congress should call upon him for it; but he should not volunteer the service. I had received a Letter from Mr Thomas Loring of Hingham, about a Register for the Schooner Amistad, purchased at auction at New London, under a decree of the District Court, sold for Salvage.— Mr Woodbury said he had received a Letter on the same subject this day, and would have enquiry concerning it made: upon which I agreed to call again to-morrow I said something concerning the case of the Amistad Negroes, and that I proposed to see the Attorney General, respecting them— Miss Cutts came this afternoon and took tea here; and in the Evening came to escort her home— Mr Parris the Comptroller was also here with Mr Wood, the Minister of the Presbyterian church Among the Letters which I received this day was one from John P. Bigelow Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts enclosing my certificate of election as a member of the 27th. Congress, and a list of all the votes cast in the 12th. Congressional District at the Election—
28. IV. Saturday.

My old Piedmontese man servant Giusta, whom I picked up, at Amsterdam in June 1814. a stray deserter from Napoleon’s army in his disastrous Russian campaign, who served me faithfully till the 3d. of March 1829. when I left him as steward of the President’s house to my successor there, Andrew Jackson, called to see me this morning.— Antoine’s life with a little embroidery from the hand of an imaginative novelist, would make an amusing and instructive tale— He married at our house in 1818 an English girl who from our kitchen at Ealing came over with us to this country, and has been to him an excellent wife. Tis pity they have never had a child— They lived two or three years with President Jackson; but could not abide his negro slaves and his savage temper— They left him and kept five or six years a small oyster and coffee house, in which he amassed a fund sufficient for them to live comfortably on its income—he purchased a small lot and tenement upon which they live, and where like Diocletian he cultivates cabbages, and lettuce, and celery. He went home two years ago to visit his relations and was gone more than a year.— He found them poor and miserable, and his brother ruined by habits of intemperance— Good humoured and social, Antoine had acquired in this Country a habit of free speaking which on his return home soon brought him under the surveillance of the police— He came back and brought one of his nephews with him But he casts lingering looks towards the natale solum and intends to dispose of all his property here, and go back to spend his last days in the land of his birth.

Mrs Pinkney is the widow of the second William Pinkney, a lost Pleiad— She came to solicit my influence to obtain a subordinate Clerkship in the House of Representatives, for her eldest Son John Sperry, 18 years of age— A younger son, 15 years old is already a midshipman in the Navy as a constructive Tennessean by the adoption of Mr Foster late a Senator from that State— I called again on the Secretary of the Treasury. The comptroller had answered Mr Loring’s letter, and confirmed by implication the refusal of the Collector at New-London to issue papers for the purchaser of the Amistad. Mr Woodbury said that he would make the collector decide the question directly and send the decision to me on Monday. He said the interest on the Arkansas bonds for the Smithsonian fund, had been regularly and punctually paid— I called twice at the Office of the Attorney General, but he was not there— At the Bank of the Metropolis where I received a balance of 3. dollars 20 cents which has been lying there upwards of two years. At the U.S. branch Bank, Mr Richard Smith told me that he had concluded to act as Executor of Mrs Hay’s Will. My wife spent this Evening with her brother Mary with Mrs Talbot, and Mary-Louisa at a party at General Jesup’s.
29. IV. Sunday.
