At the second Presbyterian Church in the morning I heard a Mr Moore, whose text was from John 11.38 [“]Jesus therefore, again groaning in himself cometh to the grave— It was a cave, and a stone lay upon it.” The first clause of the verse—the argument of the preacher was humanitarian— That Jesus was a perfect man subject to all the sinless infirmities of human nature— The argument of his divinity was not encountered; but was taken for granted— A much knottier point— That he lived and suffered and died as a man can hardly be questioned by any one who believes that he ever existed— His superhuman nature so often asserted by himself—his express declaration—before Abraham was I am—the very name by which God commanded Moses to call him— The affirmation of St. Paul that by him, God made the world, his continual assumption of the two characters, son of God and Son of Man compel me to believe that he was more than man— I cannot mythologize his miracles—and least of all that of his resurrection from the dead. His gospel is a standing miracle which I cannot controvert—his divinity is a mystery which I cannot believe, and which I see no necessity for believing; any more than the eternity of future punishments. I was not much pleased with Mr Moore’s discourse; which was full of dark and gloomy imagery, without urging any profitable doctrine or exciting any cheerful sentiment— The congregation is yet very thin— The seceders claim the church and I have an unanswered Letter from then demanding my concurrence with or acquiescence in their claim— But they hold their meetings as yet, at what is called the Medical College.— The secession as I understand was occasioned by the engagement of Mr Wood a New-England Congregationalist, as preacher in this presbyterian Church— After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the first Sunday in Advent, and a Mr Berry a native of the Island of Jamaica, educated at the University of Cambridge in England preached from Psalm 19.6. “His going forth is from the end of the heaven, and his circuit unto the ends of it, and there is nothing hid from the heat thereof.” The Sermon began with a superficial analysis of the two parts of this most beautiful Psalm, between which he did not appear to understand the admirable connection— There was no want of ingenuity or of handsome composition in the discourse; but what it was after I could not discover, unless it was to reprobate the practice of hanging up paintings on religious subjects in churches—a doctrine for which there might be some occasion in England but for which there can be none here.— The Evening service now begins here at half past 3— Mr. Berry did not finish till after Sunset, and he had much difficulty in reading the last pages of his Sermon— He just made out to announce four Stanzas of a hymn; but the choir could see to sing only two of them— Mrs Frye took tea here. My wife and Mary went home with her, and spent the Evening there—
30— VI:30. Monday.

Dr Toule, the husband of the Lady who some three years ago, painted my portrait, called on me this morning with a request that I would give her another sitting as she had been taken sick and left the picture unfinished before— I promised to visit her at her residence next Thursday before noon— Dr Todson came to say that he has a claim for compensation, for a translation of the Danish Tariff made by him for the Department of State, but for which the Secretary Mr Forsyth had no fund to pay him. He proposed to petition Congress for it, and asked my advice whether to present it, at the approaching Session, or to wait for the next Congress. I said he had better offer it now; not with an expectation of obtaining any thing at this short Session—but the claim may gain some advancement upon the business of the next Congress.— Dr Todson has been two years Consul of the United States at Altena, but found it would not give him bread— He needs some small office for subsistence, and has talents and learning which may be usefully employed. Mr Hawley came, and introduced Mr Berry, the gentleman, who assisted him in his official services yesterday— Mr Berry said he had heard me deliver the Lecture upon Faith at the Tabernacle in New-York, and he thought there were four thousand persons present— I doubt if the building will hold three thousand— Miss Cutts was also here; and Mr Henry the Member of the House of Representatives, from Beaver and Mercer Counties, Pennsylvania;—with Mrs. Henry; and their little daughter— I went to the Office of the Attorney General, Gilpin; then to his house, and again to his Office where at last I found him— The Commissioner of the Land-Office Whitcomb was with him. I spoke to him of the case of the Negroes of the Amistad, to come before the Supreme Court of the United States at their Session next January, on appeal, by the U.S. District Attorney from the decision of the District and Circuit U.S. Courts in Connecticut— Mr Gilpin had received a Letter from Mr Baldwin requesting that the case may be taken up, the first week of the Courts sitting, but thought there would be difficulty in taking it up out of its turn— I desired Mr Gilpin to submit to the consideration of the President the expedient of having the case dismissed by consent, without argument; for which I urged obvious reasons, and which he said would deserve serious consideration— I had called on the Secretary of State Forsyth; and had much conversation with him upon China, and New Zealand, and the North-eastern boundary— Mr Fendall was here this Evening; and Mr D. C. Harris from Baltimore, who comes to accompany me to that City to-morrow
